fields.title: Profile
fields.content:
# Paul Ahern
![Paul Ahern at Gougane Barra](/media/img/ahernp200x200.png "Paul Ahern at Gougane Barra")
I was born and educated in Ireland and then came to work in London. 1990-2006: Worked in the IT department of Natwest Bank, mainly as a COBOL programmer. Returned to Cork in 2006. 2006-2007: While looking for a mountain by the sea to build my retirement home on, I completed an Artificial Intelligence MSc course at University College Cork. 2008-2010: Worked in Web Support for Premiere Global Services. My team answered questions from SAP staff about using Adobe Connect. In 2008 I purchased the site for my place in the country at [Rooska](/rooska/ "Rooska") on the south side of Bantry Bay. Phase 1, planting trees, building roads, walls and a barn was completed in 2010. 2010-2011: Returned to London and started work as a Web Developer for Steel Business Briefing. Dec 2011-Nov 2012: Worked as a Web Developer for [ReportLab](http://www.reportlab.com). Nov 2012-present: Working as a Web Developer for [digitalis](http://digitalisreputation.co.uk/).

# Applications

[Firefox](/firefox/),
[emacs](/emacs/),
[Google Chrome](/google-chrome/),
[Libre Office](/libre-office/),
[Vim](/vim-editor/),
[Windows](/windows/).

## Briefly Mentioned

### TiddlyWiki

A [TiddlyWiki](http://tiddlywiki.com) consists of a single HTML page which contains all of the text as well as CSS 
and JavaScript which provide all the functionality.

An old [TiddlyWiki](/media/download/twahernp.html), 
version of this site is available. Right-click and save for a copy 
of this or an empty [TiddlyWiki](/media/download/tw.html)
(TiddlyWikis tend to be over 500kB in size so the save may 
take a few seconds).

Security changes in Firefox 15 mean you will need the
[TiddlyFox](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/tiddlyfox/)
add-on to save new TiddlyWikis.

### GRand Unified Bootloader version 2

Change menu defaults, such as timeout, by editing `/etc/default/grub`.

GRUB2 automatically includes installed Linux kernel versions on its menu. 
Remove older entries from the menu by uninstalling the older `linux-image` packages.

Update the menu by issuing the command `sudo update-grub`.

### Pandoc

[Pandoc](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/) converts files from one markup format into another. Including, as of version 1.6, from Markdown to [epub](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/epub.html).

fields.title: Tools
fields.content:
# Tools

Tools:
[Cardgen](/tools/cardgen/),
[Compare](/tools/compare/),
[Deduplicate](/tools/deduplicate/),
[Match](/tools/match/).

## Django Markdown Content Manager

DMCM is a simple Content Management System in which website pages are served on request by the Django web framework using content stored on a database as text in the [Markdown](/markdown/) format. This site is implemented using DMCM.

The source code is available at [github](https://github.com/ahernp/DMCM).

### Previous Version

In the previous version, each page was published by writing a separate *.html* document to the web server. This approach combined the efficiency of serving static HTML with the flexibility of a dynamic
back-end for changing the site contents.

[Documentation](/media/doc/dmcm "Full Documentation"); 
Download: [dmcm_0.2.zip](/media/download/dmcm_0.2.zip).

fields.title: Libre Office
fields.content:
# Libre Office

## Product

Libre Office is an office suite available from [libreoffice.org](http://libreoffice.org). Versions can be downloaded for MS Windows as well as Linux.

## Calc

* `Ctrl+D`: Copy contents and formatting from topmost cells to rest of selected range in Calc.
* Filter Items in a List:

    1. Populate column `F` with `0` or `1` depending on if the value in on that row of column `C` is listed in column `H`.
    2. Define column `H` as a range called List (Data > Define Range).
    3. Place the following in `F2` and use it to populate the rest of column `F`: `=COUNTIF(List,C2)`
    4. Sort using column `F` to group all of the matching data together.

## Writer

### Red Triangle Bullet Points

1. Create New Style:
    1. Format > Styles and Formatting > Character Styles
    1. Right-click Default > New
    1. Organizer tab > Give new style a name
    1. Font Effects tab > Choose font color
    1. OK
1. Update List 1 Style:
    1. Format > Styles and Formatting > List Styles 1.
    1. Right-click List 1 > Modify
    1. Options tab:
        1. Character Style > Choose new style created above
        1. Character > Choose triangle from Webdings font
    1. Position tab > Numbering followed by > choose Nothing to reduce indent
    1. OK
1. Use new List 1 Style:
    1. Apply Style > More > List Styles > Choose List 1
    1. Amended List 1 style should be used by all new lists

fields.title: UK Postcodes
fields.content:
# UK Postcodes

What they are and how to find them.

## Postcode Structure

UK postcodes are alphanumeric and between five and eight characters long 
(including a single space separating the outward and inward parts of the code), 
e.g. the code for the House of Commons is SW1A 0AA.

The 'Outward' part of the postcode denotes the postal district - for example RH 
for the Redhill area, and then the following number distinguishes the post town - 
broadly speaking the Delivery Office which services the local area. So RH1 is 
Redhill itself, RH10 is Crawley. With larger towns there may be more than 1 number 
in the outward section - Crawley includes RH10 and RH11. The 'Inward' part denotes 
particular parts of the town / Delivery Office area, with the first part - the number - 
being a sector, and the final two letters denoting a group of houses within that area.

For more see [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_codes_in_the_United_Kingdom).

## To Find a Postcode

1. Go to [postcode.royalmail.com](http://postcode.royalmail.com).
2. Enter the Building Number or Building Name in the fields provided.
3. Enter the Street name.
4. The previous two values are often sufficient but to reduce the 
   number of matches you can enter the Town name as well.
5. Press the "Find Postcode" button.
6. All matching addresses and postcodes are listed. 
   Click on one to see a map showing its location.

## To Find an Address from a Postcode

1. Go to [postcode.royalmail.com](http://postcode.royalmail.com).
2. Click on the "Find an address" tab.
3. Enter the Postcode in the field provided.
4. Press the "Find an Address" button.
5. The address is displayed along with a map showing its location.

fields.title: Firefox
fields.content:
# Firefox

## Add-ons

1. [Adblock Plus](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/adblock-plus/): 
Prevents downloading of advertisements on web pages. Subscribe to EasyList.
1. [Add to Search Bar](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/add-to-search-bar/):
Make any pages' search functionality available in the Search Bar.
1. [ColorZilla](http://www.colorzilla.com/firefox/):
Advanced Eyedropper, Color Picker, Palette Viewer, etc.
1. [EpubReader](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/epubreader/):
Read E-Books in epub format.
1. [Firebug](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/firebug/):
JavaScript debugger.
1. [FireFTP](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/fireftp/):
FTP client.
1. [Firesizer](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-us/firefox/addon/firesizer/):
Set window to specific size.
1. [Font Finder](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/font-finder/):
Analyze the font information of any element on a page.
1. [Foxclocks](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/foxclocks/):
Times around the world in Status Bar.
1. [iReader](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/ireader/):
Makes web pages more readable.
1. [Noia 4](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/noia-4/):
Theme.
1. [Nuke anything](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/nuke-anything-enhanced/):
Hide selected objects on web page. Can be useful prior to printing.
1. [Selenium IDE](http://seleniumhq.org/download/):
Record-and-playback of interactions with the browser.
1. [Speed Dial](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/speed-dial/developers):
Customize new tabs.
1. [sqlite-manager](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/sqlite-manager/):
Manage all your [SQLite](http://www.sqlite.org/) databases.
1. [TiddlyFox](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/tiddlyfox/):
Allow saving of TiddlyWikis.
1. [Web Developer](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/web-developer/):
Many Web Developer tools.

## Configuration

* Open links in same Tab/Window: `about:config` > `browser.link.open_newwindow` > Change value to 1.

## AwesomeBar Wildcards

Use one of these wildcards (delimited by a space) in the Firefox AwesomeBar to filter the results.

Enter the filter `browser.urlbar` in about:config to see them all.

1. **#** Returns results that match the text in the title.
2. **@** Returns results that match the text in the URL.
3. ***** Returns only results that are from the bookmarks.
4. **^** Returns only results that are from the browser's history.
5. **+** Returns only results that have been tagged.

## Clear Cache

1. At the top of the Firefox window, click the History menu, and select Clear Recent History....
1. In the Time range to clear field choose everything.
1. Press the Details button if a list of tickboxes is not visible.
1. Tick all the boxes.
1. Press Clear Now button

fields.title: Linux
fields.content:
# Linux

Contents:
[Bash/zsh Command Line](#bashzsh-command-line),
[Simple Backup](#simple-backup),
[Shutdown](#ultimate-linux-shutdown-process),
[Upgrade OS](#upgrade-os),
[Lost Password](#lost-password).

## General tips

* The Advanced Linux Sound Architecture (ALSA) provides audio and MIDI functionality to the Linux operating system. Use `alsamixer` from a terminal to adjust settings. (`alsamixer -Dhw`)
* When you get a "file system is read only" error on a USB drive (mounted at sdb1) try unmounting and remounting as read/write with the following command: `sudo mount -o remount,rw /dev/sdb1`.
* Linux interprets **#!** (called a shebang), when they are the first two characters in a text file, as indicating that the file is a script and the rest of the line gives the absolute path of the interpreter. E.g. Bash #!/bin/sh; Python 3.1 #!/usr/bin/python3.1.
* Login to Gnome and KDE together by hitting CNTL+ALT+F2, logging onto that terminal and entering the command `startx gnome -- :1` (or `startx kde -- :1` depending on which is already started). Swap between the desktops using CNTL+ALT+F7 and CNTL+ALT+F8.

## Bash/zsh Command Line

* Make the command-line prompt reflect Version Control using [vcprompt](/vcprompt/).
* Terminal Multiplexer Byobu
([Man Page](http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/natty/en/man1/byobu.1.html);
Add new terminal: `F2`; Scroll through terminals: `F3` and `F4`).
* Search for string in files (include sub-directories): `grep -rl "string" *`.
* Delete all empty `.xml` files: `find . -name "*.xml" -size 0 -exec rm {} \;`.
* Recursively remove folders and their contents: `rm -rf`.
* List files with **/** added to directory names and **\*** to executables: `ls -F`.
* Mass rename (remove BG suffix): `for i in *BG.png; do mv $i ${i%%BG.png}.png; done`.
* `rename 's/ /_/g' *`: Replace spaces with underscores in file names.
* Checksum: `md5sum ubuntu-10.04-desktop-i386.iso`.
* Find which executable will be used: `which python`.
* Change to the previous working directory: `cd -`.
* Substitution: `!$` Repeats last argument of previous command; `!!` Repeat previous line command; `^foo^bar^` Repeat the previous shell command but replace string "foo" with "bar".
* `echo $?`: Display exit code.
* `su userid`: Switch User.
* traceroute and ping combined: `mtr google.com`.
* Run graphical application as root: `gksudo nautilus`.
* Create link: `ln [-s] file [link]`.
* Reconnect to network connection by restarting network manager service: `sudo service network-manager restart`.
* Monitor several logs: `tail -f [logfile1] [logfile2]...`.
* `df`: Show disk usage.
* Job Control: `jobs` List background jobs; `bg [jobspec]` Run job in background; `fg [jobspec]` Bring specific or most recent job to foreground; `kill %1` Kill first listed job.

### Simple Backup

    # Simple Sync
    simple_sync() {
        SOURCE=$1"/"
        DEST=$2
        echo "Backing up newer versions of files in $SOURCE to $DEST"
        rsync -auz --stats --modify-window=1 $SOURCE $DEST
        SOURCE=$2"/"
        DEST=$1
        echo "Backing up newer versions of files in $SOURCE to $DEST"
        rsync -auz --stats --modify-window=1 $SOURCE $DEST
    }
    simple_sync "Documents" "/media/SANDISK/work"

## Ultimate Linux shutdown process

If all is stuck, and even Ctrl+Alt+backspace does not work, remember this mnemonic: **R**aising **S**kinny **E**lephants **I**s **U**tterly **B**oring:

* ALT+SysRq+**r** (put keyboard in raw mode)
* ALT+SysRq+**s** (sync the disk)
* ALT+SysRq+**e** (terminate all processes)
* ALT+SysRq+**i** (kill all processes)
* ALT+SysRq+**u** (remount all file systems read only)
* ALT+SysRq+**b** (reboot the system)

(SysRq is the same button as print screen on most keyboards)

Less drastically, you can use ALT+SysRq+**k** to kill all processes on the current virtual console (has the effect of restarting the X server).

## Upgrade OS

OS: Ubuntu; Browser: Firefox.

1.  Backup data. 
2.  Install new OS.
3.  Copy Backup data to new set up.
5.  Populate .gnupg with backed up files.
7.  Install package `numlockx` (enable NumLock in X11 sessions).
7.  Install package `ttf-mscorefonts-installer` (web-standard fonts).
7.  Install package `ttf-ubuntu-fonts-family`.
7.  Install package `ubuntu-restricted-extras`.
8.  Setup Local LAMP server for development:
    1. `sudo tasksel install lamp-server` 
    ([Tasksel Info](https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Tasksel))
    2. `sudo apt-get install phpmyadmin`
11. Change login screen wallpaper: `sudo cp /usr/share/applications/gnome-appearance-properties.desktop /usr/share/gdm/autostart/LoginWindow/`.
1. Download configuration files: [.zshrc](/media/download/zshrc.txt) and [.vimrc](/media/download/vimrc.txt).

### OpenDNS

Add OpenDNS servers by editing `/etc/dhcp3/dhclient.conf` and appending the following line to the document:

    prepend domain-name-servers 208.67.222.222,208.67.220.220;

### Logout Keyboard Shortcut

To re-enable Control+Alt+Backspace shortcut to kill the X server:

1. Open Keyboard preferences.
1. Choose Layouts Tab.
1. Press Options Button.
1. Find "Key sequence to kill the x server' option on list.
1. Tick to enable.

### Change positions of Window Icons in Gnome

1. Run `gconf-editor`.
2. Navigate to: `Apps > Metacity > General > button_layout`.
3. Update to `close,minimize,maximize:menu` for buttons on the left or `menu:minimize,maximize,close` for buttons on the right.

### Use xmonad Window Manager in Gnome

1. Install packages `sudo apt-get install xmonad dmenu`.
1. Run `gconf-editor`.
2. Navigate to: `Desktop > Gnome > Session > required_components > windowmanager`.
3. change the value from `gnome-wm` to `xmonad`.

xmonad keyboard shortcuts [cheatsheet](/media/download/Xmbindings.svg). 
`~/.xmonad/xmonad.hs` [configuration file](/media/download/xmonad.hs).

### Monitor Network Usage

1. Install vnstat: `sudo apt-get install vnstat`.
1. Create database: `sudo vnstat -u -i eth0`.
1. Show monthly usage: `vnstat -m`.

## Lost Password

Steps to recover lost password in Ubuntu:

1. Choose your Recovery Mode from Grub menu.
2. On the Recovery Menu choose "Drop to root shell prompt".
3. At the command prompt enter `ls /home` to list Userids. (optional)
4. Enter `passwd <userid>` to change the password of that Userid.
5. Enter `exit`.
6. On the Recovery Menu choose "Resume Normal Boot".

fields.title: Windows
fields.content:
# Microsoft Windows

## General Tips

Select multiple items in the Task Bar by holding down the Control Key and clicking on them.

### Shortcut Keys

*  `Alt+D` Go to Browser Address field
*  `Alt+F4` Close application
*  `Alt+Tab` cycle through open applications
*  `PrintScreen` Place image of screen in clipboard
*  `Alt+PrintScreen` Place image of active window in clipboard
*  `Windows Key+D` Minimize all windows (toggle)
*  `Windows Key+E` Open Windows Explorer
*  `Windows Key+F` Find files on your computer
*  `Windows Key+L` Lock your computer
*  `Windows Key+R` Opens the Run Program Dialog

## Recycle Bin

Stop having to "confirm delete" when merely moving data to the Recycle Bin:

1.  Right-click the Recycle Bin icon
2.  Select "Properties"
3.  Un-tick "Display delete confirmation dialog"
4.  Click "OK."

## Single-Click

Enable Single-click to open items:

1.  Key Windows Key+E to open Windows Explorer
2.  Choose Folder Options from the Tools pull-down menu
3.  In the General tab choose "Single-click to open an item"

## Microsoft Office

*  Switch off dynamic menus in all Microsoft Office 2003 applications using the 
"Always Show Full Menus" checkbox in the Options Tab under Tools > Customise in any 
of those applications.
*  To swap between files in Microsoft Office (versions 97 onwards) key Control + F6.

### Word

*  Disable the Reading Layout: Go to Tools > Options > General. Uncheck "Allow starting 
in Reading Layout".
*  Change Ctrl+V to Paste text without the formatting into a Word document 
([see](http://office.microsoft.com/en-gb/help/HA010429611033.aspx)).

### Excel

*   Ctrl+D: Copy contents and formatting from topmost cells to rest of selected range.
*   Filter Items in a List:
    1.  Populate column F with 0 or 1 depending on if the value in on that row of 
    column C is listed in column H.
    2.  Place the following in F2 and use it to populate the rest of column F: =COUNTIF(H:H,C2)
    3.  Sort using column F to group all of the matching data together.
    4.  In each record, the value in column C is checked. If it is in the list in column H, 
    the record passes through the filter.

### Outlook

*   Stop the Reading Pane in Outlook 2003 from marking emails as read by going to 
Tools > Options > Other tab > Reading Pane button. 
Then make sure that both the "Mark items as read" options are unchecked.

#### Add Mailbox

If you have permission to view another mailbox then here are the steps to add it to those 
displayed in your Outlook session:

1.  From the Tools menu, select E-mail Accounts.
2.  In the E-mail section, select View or change existing e-mail accounts and click Next.
3.  Select Microsoft Exchange Server.
4.  Click Change.
5.  Click More Settings.
6.  Select the Advanced tab.
7.  In the Mailboxes section, click Add.
8.  In the Add Mailbox text box, type the name of the mailbox.
9.  Click Ok, Ok, Next and Finish to apply the change.

fields.title: Rooska
fields.content:
# Rooska

Contents:
[Maps](#maps),
[Directions](#directions),
[Before](#before),
[Wall](#development-wall),
[Mountain](#development-mountain),
[Roads](#development-roads),
[Quarrying](#development-quarrying),
[Barn](#development-barn),
[Spring 2011](#growth-spring-2011),
[Spring 2012](#spring-2012),
[Spring 2013](#spring-2013).


Rooska is the name of the place, next to Bantry Bay, where I bought 30 acres of mountainside.
My plan is to build a place in the country for holidays and my eventual retirement.

So far I have built a barn and [planted](/planting/) 15 acres with trees.

## Maps

[![Map of Southwest Ireland](/media/img/thumb/RooskaMap0.jpg "Map of Southwest Ireland")](/media/img/RooskaMap0.jpg "Map of Southwest Ireland")
[![Map of Rooska](/media/img/thumb/RooskaMap1.jpg "Map of Rooska")](/media/img/RooskaMap1.jpg "Map of Rooska")
[![Aerial Photo of Rooska](/media/img/thumb/RooskaSat.jpg "Aerial Photo of Rooska")](/media/img/RooskaSat.jpg "Aerial Photo of Rooska")
[![Map showing boundaries and subdivisions](/media/img/thumb/RooskaMap2.jpg "Map showing boundaries and subdivisions")](/media/img/RooskaMap2.jpg "Map showing boundaries and subdivisions")

## Directions

To visit Rooska: Take the from Cork N71 West to Bantry; Just before Bantry take the turn off for Kilkrohane (first photo); Go down this road for 4 miles until you see a church on the right (second photo); At the next left (third photo) stop and walk up to the property at the end of this road.

[![N71 turn off to Kilkrohane](/media/img/thumb/Directions1.jpg "N71 turn off to Kilkrohane")](/media/img/Directions1.jpg "N71 turn off to Kilkrohane")
[![Rooska Church](/media/img/thumb/Directions2.jpg "Rooska Church")](/media/img/Directions2.jpg "Rooska Church")
[![Turnoff to Rooska](/media/img/thumb/Directions3.jpg "Turnoff to Rooska")](/media/img/Directions3.jpg "Turnoff to Rooska")

## Before

What the place looked like when I bought it (January 2008).

[![Map showing boundaries and subdivisions](/media/img/thumb/RooskaMap.jpg "Map showing boundaries and subdivisions")](/media/img/RooskaMap.jpg "Map showing boundaries and subdivisions")

## Development - Wall

In autumn 2009, a stone wall was built along my new northeast boundary.

[![Digger Preparing Ground](/media/img/thumb/Digger.jpg "Digger Preparing Ground")](/media/img/Digger.jpg "Digger Preparing Ground")

## Development - Mountain

In autumn 2009, the mountainside was dug up in preparation for [planting](planting.html) trees
in the spring of 2010.

[![Western drains in action](/media/img/thumb/drains.jpg "Western drains in action")](/media/img/drains.jpg "Western drains in action")

## Development - Roads

In spring 2010, new roads and bridges were built to provide access to the mountainside and
site of the barn at the bottom.

[![Calves blas&eacute](/media/img/thumb/ConstructionAudience.jpg "Calves blas&eacute")](/media/img/ConstructionAudience.jpg "Calves blas&eacute")

[![Stone Road](/media/img/thumb/rooskaStoneRoad.jpg "Stone Road")](/media/img/rooskaStoneRoad.jpg "Stone Road")

## Development - Quarrying

In spring 2010, a rocky knoll in the field next door was quarried to provide stone for
the new roads, to build up the site of the barn and for additional walls near the bridges.

[![Before Quarrying](/media/img/thumb/RooskaLowerField.jpg "Before Quarrying")](/media/img/RooskaLowerField.jpg "Before Quarrying")

fields.title: CV
fields.content:
# Paul Ahern, Python Programmer ## My Story So Far Having worked at Natwest bank in London for 15 years developing Retail Banking applications, using the COBOL programming language, in 2006 I moved back to Ireland to build a place in the country. While there, I attended an MSc course in Artificial Intelligence and worked on a helpdesk supporting various web meeting products. Since September 2010, I have been working in London as a Web Developer mostly using Python and Django. As an Irish citizen I am eligible to work in the UK. ## Technical Skills *Programming:* Python, Javascript, COBOL, Java
*Scripting:* Bash, JCL, Rexx, Clist
*Databases:* MySQL, SQLite, DB2
*Web:* Django, HTML, CSS
*Version Control:* Git, Mercurial, Endevor
*Management:* Pivotal Tracker, INFOSYS
*IDE:* Eclipse/Aptana ## Education **1987-1990** BA Computer Studies, University College Cork: * Majored in Information Technology; Minored in Geography. **2006-2007** MSc Computer Science, UCC: * *Subjects* – Computer Security, Mobile Applications and various aspects of Artificial Intelligence. * *Projects* – Building a University Timetabling tool using Constraint-Based programming techniques and modelling an adaptive Spam filtering system. ## Experience **November 2012** joined Digitalis Reputations in London as a Web Developer. **2011-2012** at ReportLab in London: > Worked as a Web Developer building and maintaining sites using the Django web framework and the Python and Javascript programming languages. > Built several web sites which allow organisations to provide links to PDF output which is dynamically generated from their own data sets using the Reportlab core product. > My team has also built a Django-based wizard which allows users to buy foreign exchange. This has been rolled out across several financial institutions. We are now in the process of internationalising it by using different languages and local currencies. **2010-2011** at Steel Business Briefing in London: > Worked as a Web Developer building sites using the Django web framework and the Python and Javascript programming languages. > Main components built: >* *Advanced Filter* – Subclassed ModelAdmin to allow filtering on ranges of data and many-to-many relationships as well as ForeignKeys. >* *Data Import Harness* – Programs and control data to populate the new database with legacy data. >* *Invoicing* – Redesigned creation and processing of invoices. **2008-2010** at Premiere Global Services in Ireland: > Worked as a Web Technical Specialist answering client questions about using web-meeting products (Adobe Connect, Microsoft Live Meeting & Webex). **2006-2007** in Ireland: > Attended a full-time taught MSc course at UCC titled: Intelligent Systems for Business and Manufacturing. > Learned to drive. **1990-2006** at Natwest Bank in London: > For seven years I worked on the Live Support Team, helping to keep vital bank systems running. This included two years on the Helpdesk dealing with problems reported by non-IT staff across the countrywide branch network. > For several of those years I also worked as a duty-programmer. Working at night to see that the batch programs completed successfully and dealing immediately with any problems that arose. > The remainder of my time was spent on various application development teams. One of which build a system which automatically sent letters to Customers when changes occurred to the Standing Orders or Direct Debits on their accounts. > As a member of Application Development teams I participated in the end-to-end process of designing, documenting, building and implementing systems. From collecting requirements from users through writing design documents and implementation plans as well as coding and testing my role covered the full development process. > Apart from the OS390 IBM mainframe environment, much of my time was spent using Microsoft Word and Visio to capture and communicate the requirements and design of new and amended systems.

fields.title: DMCM
fields.content:
# Django Markdown Content Manager

DMCM is a simple Content Management System in which website pages are served on request by the Django web framework using content stored on a database as text in the [Markdown](/markdown/) format. This site is implemented using DMCM.

The source code is available at [github](https://github.com/ahernp/DMCM).

## Previous Version

In the previous version, each page was published by writing a separate *.html* document to the web server. This approach combined the efficiency of serving static HTML with the flexibility of a dynamic
back-end for changing the site contents.

[Documentation](/media/doc/dmcm "Full Documentation"); 
Download: [dmcm_0.2.zip](/media/download/dmcm_0.2.zip).

fields.title: emacs
fields.content:
# emacs

Contents:
[emacs](#emacs),
[Keyboard Shortcuts](#keyboard-shortcuts),
[Movement](#movement),
[Search](#search),
[File](#file),
[Marking](#marking),
[Yank and Kill](#yank-and-kill),
[Commands](#commands),
[Remote/Sudo Editing](#remotesudo-editing),
[Modes](#modes),
[Org-mode](#org-mode),
[ibuffer](#ibuffer),
[dired](#dired),
[bookmark-list](#bookmark-list),
[Macros](#macros),
[.emacs.el](#emacsel),
[ahernp.el](#ahernpel),
[Download](#download).

Ref:
[GNU Emacs Manual](http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/index.html), [EmacsWiki](http://www.emacswiki.org/), [Shortcuts](http://www.math.uh.edu/~bgb/emacs_keys.html), [Emacs](http://xahlee.org/emacs/emacs.html), [Elisp Tutorial](http://xahlee.org/emacs/elisp.html).
Start in terminal: `emacs -nw`.

## Keyboard Shortcuts

* `C-/`: Undo.
* `C-z`: Suspend emacs and return to the shell. Resume with the command `%emacs`.
* `C-c >`: Indent the block 4 spaces (Python mode). `C-c <` will remove 4 spaces of indentation.
* `F10`: Access Menu bar.
* `C-x C-e`: Evaluate previous [elisp](http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/elisp/index.html) expression.
* In the minibuffer:
    * `C-q C-j`: Carriage return.
    * `C-q TAB`: TAB character.
* `C-x 1`: Hide other windows.
* `C-x 2`: Split window into two windows positioned one above the other.
* `C-x 3`: Split window into two windows positioned side by side.
* `C-x o`: Select other window.
* `M-x ielm`: Start Emacs-Lisp interactive interpreter.

### Movement

* `C-l`: Toggle scroll current line to middle, top & bottom of window. (`C-L`)
* `M-g g`: Jump to specified line.

### Search

* `C-s`: Incremental search forward.
    * `C-w`: Adds the word following point to the search buffer.
    * `C-y`: Adds the rest of the current line to the search buffer.
* `C-r`: Incremental search backward.
* `M-x occur`: Show all matches for regex.
* `M-%`: Query replace.
* `C-M-s`: Regular expression incremental search.
* `M-x replace-regexp`: Regular expression replacement ([regex](http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/elisp/Regular-Expressions.html)).
* Replace in several files at once:
    * `M-x find-grep-dired`: This gives us a buffer of files containing the string (includes subdirectories).
    * `% m .json$ RET`: Mark the **.json** files.
    * `Q`: Query replace in all marked files. At this point, Emacs will cycle through every match in every file and ask you to confirm the replacement. If you press `!`, it will replace the rest of the matches in the current file, and start prompting you for the next; `Y` will replace every match in every file with no further prompting.
    * `C-x s`: Save every modified file.

### File

* `C-x C-w`: Save the current buffer as a specified file name (write-file). 
* `C-x d`: File Manager. Followed by `C-x C-q` for editable dired mode.
* `C-x C-v RET`: Reload buffer from disk.
* `C-x C-b`: List open buffers.

### Marking

* `C-SPC`: Set mark to the current location.
* `C-x C-x`: Swap point and mark.
* `C-u C-SPC`: Cycle through mark ring.
* `C-x h`: Make region contain the entire buffer ("Select all").
* `M-h`: Make region contain the current paragraph.
* `C-x n n`: Narrow buffer to the current region.
* `C-x n w`: Restore ("widen") buffer.

### Yank and Kill

* `C-k`: Kill line.
* `C-x k`: Kill buffer.
* `C-w`: Kill region ("cut").
* `M-w`: Save region to kill ring without deleting ("copy").
* `M-d`: Kill next word.
* `M-k`: Kill to end of sentence.
* `C-y`: Yanks last killed text.
* `M-y`: Replace yanked text with previously killed text.

## Commands

* `M-x ediff`: Compare two files and highlight their differences.
* `M-x eval-buffer`: Run emacs lisp file in current buffer.
* `M-x shell`: Start shell.
* `M-x grep`: Run grep.
* `M-x man`: Show man pages.

## Remote/Sudo Editing

* Enter filename in the form `/[server]:[filename]` or `/[user@server]:[filename]`. Will be prompted for remote password.
* Need to have added `(setq tramp-default-method "ssh")` to the `.emacs.el` file.
* `C-x +`: Sudo find file.
* `C-x !`: Sudo reopen file.

## Modes

### Org-mode

* [orgmode.org](http://orgmode.org): [Compact Guide](http://orgmode.org/guide/index.html), [Tutorials](http://orgmode.org/worg/org-tutorials/index.html).
* `C-u C-c .`: Insert Date * Time.
* `C-c .`: Insert Date.

### ibuffer

* `m`: Mark.
* `u`: Unmark.
* `*u`: Mark unsaved.
* `S`: Save marked buffer.
* `D`: Close marked buffers.
* `**`: Unmark all.
* `%m`: Mark by mode name (e.g. all html files, all java files).
* `%f`: Mark by file path (e.g. all files in a dir).

### dired

* `Enter`: Open the file.
* `a`: Open the file and close the dired buffer.
* `o`: Open the file in a split window, so the dir is still visible.
* `q`: Close the dir.
* `C`: Copy file.
* `R`: Rename file.
* `D`: Delete file.
* `m`: mark a file.
* `u`: unmark.
* `U`: unmark all marked.
* `t`: switch marked/unmarked.
* `%m`: mark by regular expression.
* `g`: refresh dir listing.
* `^`: Go to parent dir..
* `+`: create a dir.
* `Z`: compress/decompress the file by gzip.

### bookmark-list

* `C-x r m <RET>`: Set the bookmark for the visited file, at point. 
* `C-x r m bookmark <RET>`: Set the bookmark named bookmark at point (bookmark-set). 
* `C-x r b bookmark <RET>`: Jump to the bookmark named bookmark (bookmark-jump). 
* `C-x r l`: List all bookmarks (list-bookmarks). 
* `M-x bookmark-delete`: Delete a named bookmark.

## Macros

* `F3`: Start recording macro.
* `F4`: Stop recording macro.
* `F4`: Play back macro once.
* `M-5 F4`: Play back macro 5 times.
* `M-0 F4`: Play back macro over and over until it fails.

## .emacs.el

    ; Start in *scratch* buffer
    (setq inhibit-startup-screen t)

    ; Remember recently accessed files
    (require 'recentf)
    (recentf-mode 1)

    ; Add directory to load path
    (add-to-list 'load-path (expand-file-name "~/elisp"))

    ; Add bespoke functions
    (load "ahernp")

    ; Add icicles directory to list
    (add-to-list 'load-path "~/elisp/icicles/")
    (require 'icicles)
    (icy-mode 1)

    ; Activate crosshairs cursor
    (require 'crosshairs)
    (global-set-key (kbd "M-+") 'crosshairs-mode)

    ; turn on highlight matching parens when cursor is on one
    (show-paren-mode 1)

    ; Use ibuffer instead of the default list-buffers
    (defalias 'list-buffers 'ibuffer)

    ; Find and Exclude
    (defalias 'lml 'list-matching-lines)
    (defalias 'dml 'delete-matching-lines)
    (defalias 'dnm 'delete-non-matching-lines)

    ; Markdown
    (autoload 'markdown-mode "markdown-mode.el"
      "Major mode for editing Markdown files" t)
    (setq auto-mode-alist
          (cons '("\\.text" . markdown-mode) auto-mode-alist))

    ; Org-mode: Enable flyspell mode
    (add-hook 'org-mode-hook
              (lambda ()
                ;; flyspell mode for spell checking everywhere
                (flyspell-mode 1)))

    (global-set-key (kbd "C-c j") 'flyspell-check-previous-highlighted-word)

    ; Tramp mode to access remote files
    (setq tramp-default-method "ssh")

    ; Allow save as root
    (eval-after-load "tramp"
      '(progn
         (defvar sudo-tramp-prefix 
           "/sudo::" 
           (concat "Prefix to be used by sudo commands when building tramp path "))

         (defun sudo-file-name (filename) (concat sudo-tramp-prefix filename))

         (defun sudo-find-file (filename &optional wildcards)
           "Calls find-file with filename with sudo-tramp-prefix prepended"
           (interactive "fFind file with sudo ")      
           (let ((sudo-name (sudo-file-name filename)))
             (apply 'find-file 
                    (cons sudo-name (if (boundp 'wildcards) '(wildcards))))))

         (defun sudo-reopen-file ()
           "Reopen file as root by prefixing its name with sudo-tramp-prefix and by clearing buffer-read-only"
           (interactive)
           (let* 
               ((file-name (expand-file-name buffer-file-name))
                (sudo-name (sudo-file-name file-name)))
             (progn           
               (setq buffer-file-name sudo-name)
               (rename-buffer sudo-name)
               (setq buffer-read-only nil)
               (message (concat "Set file name to " sudo-name)))))

         (global-set-key "\C-x+" 'sudo-find-file)
         (global-set-key "\C-x!" 'sudo-reopen-file)))

## ahernp.el

	; sql select results reformatter
	(defun mysql-sel-reformat (firstcol delim)
	  " Reformat results of a series of MySQL select statements.
	Remove formatting and column names."
  	  (defun replace-all (search-regex replace-regex)
  	    " Go to the start of the buffer; 
	  Replace all occurances of search-regex with replace-regex."
	    (goto-char 1)
	    (while (re-search-forward search-regex nil t)
		     (replace-match replace-regex))
	  )
	  (interactive "sEnter first column name: \nsEnter delimiter: ")
	  ; Blank out horizontal lines
	  (replace-all "^\+.*" "")
	  ; Blank out column names lines
	  (replace-all (concat "^| " firstcol " |.*") "")
	  ; Blank out numbers of rows lines
	  (replace-all "^[0-9].*" "")
	  ; Remove "| " from beginning of lines
	  (replace-all "^| " "")
	  ; Remove " |" from end of lines
	  (replace-all " |$" "")
	  ; Replace remaining "|" with the chosen delimiter
	  (replace-all " *| *" delim)
	  ; Remove blank lines
	  (replace-all "^\n" "")
	)

## Download

Download from [ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/emacs/](http://ftp.gnu.org/pub/gnu/emacs).

Install under Ubuntu using the following commands in the directory where you unpacked emacs:

 1. `sudo apt-get install libncurses5-dev`
 1. `./configure --with-xpm=no --with-jpeg=no --with-png=no --with-gif=no --without-x`
 1. `make`
 1. `sudo make install`

The `libncurses5-dev` package is needed to avoid the `emacs: Cannot open termcap database file` error when running emacs in a terminal (`emacs -nw`).

fields.title: Twinings Tea
fields.content:
# Twinings Tea

Varieties of tea available from the [Twinings](http://shop.twinings.co.uk/shop/teabag-pick-n-mix.html) website. The number of **!**'s indicates how popular that variety is with people in my office.

1. *Everyday Tea*: Blended to be a brighter tasting tea, Everyday tea is perfect all day... everyday. **!!!!**
1. *Traditional English*: A robust blend of the finest Assam, Kenyan and Ceylon teas produces a rich, revitalising cup of tea. **!!!!**
1. *Earl Grey*: Scented with bergamot flavour for a light, soothing drink. **!!!**
1. *Green Pure*: The classic, refreshing taste of pure green tea **!!**
1. *Lemon and Ginger*: A warming infusion, the spiciness of ginger is balanced with clean zesty lemon. **!!**
1. *Assam*: A strong Indian tea with a rich malty character - perfect at any time of the day. **!**
1. *Blended to Recharge*: This refreshing blend combines tangy blackcurrant and hibiscus, with ginseng which is reputed to have reviving properties. **!**
1. *Darjeeling*: A light, distinctive tea from the district renowned for producing the world's most famous tea. **!**
1. *Redbush*: The beating hot sun in Western Africa gives the redbush its juicy, refreshing flavour and copper-red colour. **!**
1. *Amber Keemun Tea*: A bright Keemun black tea with a silky smooth taste.
1. *Blackcurrant, Ginseng & Vanilla*: A luscious infusion with a rich combination of sweet blackcurrant, ginseng root and vanilla.
1. *Blended as a Digestif*: This blend combines fennel seeds with peppermint, both of which have long been used as aids to digestion.
1. *Blended as a Morning Detox*: A purifying blend, combining the fresh taste of verbena, limeflowers and lemon, which has been used for many years, with hot water, as a cleansing drink to start the day.
1. *Blended to Calm*: A soothing blend combining warming rooibos and cocoa beans with lavender and camomile, which has long been used for relaxation.
1. *Blended to Cleanse*: A blend of spearmint, long used to aid digestion; nettle, reputed to have a cleansing effect; and milk thistle, believed to have antioxidant properties.
1. *Blended to Recover*: This cleansing blend combines the fresh taste of peppermint with rooibos and milk thistle, both reputed to have antioxidant properties.
1. *Blossom Earl Grey*: We've created a stylish mix of sweet orange blossom flavour and citrus bergamot.
1. *Blueberry & Apple*: A taste of autumn with a full-bodied blend of sweet red apples and blueberry flavours.
1. *Camomile*: We've picked only the most fragrant flowers to make this light and delicate infusion.
1. *Ceylon*: A bright, medium tea with a slight citrus character. Can be served hot or cooled as a delicious iced tea.
1. *Cranberry & Sanguinello Orange*: The Sanguinello, a Spanish variety of blood orange, perfectly compliments the sharpness of cranberry.
1. *Cranberry, Rasberry & Elderflower*: Lift your senses with a delicious red berry infusion with a hint of elderflower.
1. *Golden Oolong Tea*: A sunny and sweet Oolong Tea with a fragrant taste of spring.
1. *Green Tea with Cranberry*: When summer seems a long way off, our green tea with cranberry could be just the thing to brighten your day.
1. *Green Tea with Orange & Lotus Flower*: This distinctly oriental blend combines zesty orange and a delicate hint of lotus flowers with a lightly aromatic green tea.
1. *Mulled Spice*: Full bodied Assam black tea scented with cinnamon, cloves and Christmas spice flavouring.
1. *Orange, Mango & Cinnamon*: Winter or summer? We love both. That's why we created our orange, mango & cinnamon infusion.
1. *Peppermint Pure*: A refreshing infusion with a clean taste. The cool aroma of mint is both refreshing and soothing.
1. *Pure White*: A delicate, sweet white tea, made from the unopened bud and first leaf of the Camelia Sisensis tea plant.
1. *Rose Garden*: From English country gardens to ancient Turkish palaces, there's nothing like the romance and style of a rose. 
1. *Spring White Tea*: An easy and light white tea, made from Spring picked buds; this is tea at its purest.
1. *Traditional English Decaffeinated*: A robust blend of the finest Assam, Kenyan and Ceylon teas produces a rich, revitalising cup of tea.
1. *White Tea and Pomegranate*: A delicate, light tasting white tea, perfectly balanced with the sweet fruity flavour of pomegranate.

fields.title: HTML Status Codes
fields.content:
# HTML Status Codes

## Informational 1xx

*  100 Continue
*  101 Switching Protocols

## Successful 2xx

*  200 OK
*  201 Created
*  202 Accepted
*  203 Non-Authoritative Information
*  204 No Content
*  205 Reset Content
*  206 Partial Content

## Redirection 3xx

*  300 Multiple Choices
*  301 Moved Permanently
*  302 Found
*  303 See Other
*  304 Not Modified
*  305 Use Proxy
*  306 (Unused)
*  307 Temporary Redirect

## Client Error 4xx

*  400 Bad Request
*  401 Unauthorized
*  402 Payment Required
*  403 Forbidden
*  404 Not Found
*  405 Method Not Allowed
*  406 Not Acceptable
*  407 Proxy Authentication Required
*  408 Request Timeout
*  409 Conflict
*  410 Gone
*  411 Length Required
*  412 Precondition Failed
*  413 Request Entity Too Large
*  414 Request-URI Too Long
*  415 Unsupported Media Type
*  416 Requested Range Not Satisfiable
*  417 Expectation Failed

## Server Error 5xx

*  500 Internal Server Error
*  501 Not Implemented
*  502 Bad Gateway
*  503 Service Unavailable
*  504 Gateway Timeout
*  505 HTTP Version Not Supported

From [www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html).

fields.title: Google Chrome
fields.content:
# Google Chrome

Download from [www.google.com/chrome](http://www.google.com/chrome).

## Extensions

1. [Adblock Plus](https://chrome.google.com/extensions/detail/cfhdojbkjhnklbpkdaibdccddilifddb): 
Prevents downloading of advertisements on web pages.
2. [Clickable Links](https://chrome.google.com/extensions/detail/mblbciejcodpealifnhfjbdlkedplodp): 
Turns unclickable urls & email addresses into clickable ones.
3. [Docs PDF/PowerPoint Viewer](https://chrome.google.com/extensions/detail/nnbmlagghjjcbdhgmkedmbmedengocbn): 
Automatically previews pdfs, powerpoint presentations, and other documents in Google Docs Viewer.
4. [Firebug Lite](https://chrome.google.com/extensions/search?itemlang=&hl=en-gb&q=firebug): 
Javascript Debugger.
1. [Chromey Calculator](https://chrome.google.com/extensions/detail/acgimceffoceigocablmjdpebeodphgc): 
Scrolling calculator for Chrome. Results are generated using Google and Wolfram|Alpha. ([CC Enhancer](https://chrome.google.com/extensions/detail/hfgnndipkjcpghbagmmcemdbjfclkcla))
1. [No More Windows](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/no-more-windows/ppljpblaiplljblignkngnkpnhdilkmd): 
Stop links opening new tabs or windows.
1. [Readability Redux](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/readability-redux/jggheggpdocamneaacmfoipeehedigia):
Makes web pages more readable by eliminating boilerplate.
1. [Search Results Blacklist](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/nolijncfnkgaikbjbdaogikpmpbdcdef):
Personal Blocklist from Google.
1. [Speed Dial](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/speed-dial/dgpdioedihjhncjafcpgbbjdpbbkikmi):
Customize new tabs.

Need to select Settings > Extensions > Developer Mode to allow synchronising of Extensions and Themes.

## Search

Default to getting Last Year's results:

1. Open Chrome's Settings Manage Search Engines
1. Add a new search engine under the list of ''Other search engines'' with the following values.
    * Name: *Google (recent)*
    * Keyword: *recent*
    * URL: `http://www.google.com/search?q=%s&tbs=qdr:y&tbo=1`
1. Change this to be your default search
To use `encrypted.google.com` the URL is `https://encrypted.google.com/search?q=%s`.

## Clear Cache

1. Click the Chrome menu  on the browser toolbar.
1. Select Tools.
1. Select Clear browsing data.
1. In the dialogue that appears, select the tickboxes for the types of information that you want to remove.
1. Use the menu at the top to select the amount of data that you want to delete. Select beginning of time to delete everything.
1. Click Clear browsing data.

fields.title: Python
fields.content:
# Python Programming Language

Contents:
[Notes](#notes)
([Python Debugger](#python-debugger),
[Dictionaries](#dictionaries),
[Exceptions](#exceptions),
[Operators](#operators),
[Interaction with Operating System](#interaction-with-operating-system),
[Slicing](#slicing)).
[Recipes](#recipes)
([Write File](#write-file),
[Remove Substring](#remove-substring),
[FTP](#ftp),
[Sort, Pickle, Hash](#sort-pickle-hash),
[Display Progress Percentage](#display-progress-percentage),
[Default encoding](#default-encoding)),

## Notes

Get last 3 parts of path: `'/'.join(path.split('/')[-3:]`) (e.g. `/a/b/c/d` to `b/c/d`)

In a loop: `break` ends the entire loop; `continue` ends the current iteration.

List attributes of an object: `dir(object)`. 
Reference object attributes and values via: `object.__dict__`.

Check if string is numeric: `s.isdigit()`

String and Integer formatting: `'%s%07d' % ('RPT', 7)` gives `RPT0000007`.

Identify subclasses: `issubclass(A,B)` returns `True` if A is a subclass of B. (e.g. `issubclass(self.model,Config)`)

Check for attribute: `hasattr(object,string)` Returns `True` if the string matches an attribute name.

### Python Debugger

Add the following line to start a debug session at that point in the code at runtime:

    import pdb; pdb.set_trace() # Start debugging

Commands (hit enter to repeat previous command):

* `n` Next
* `p [name]` Print
* `c` Continue
* `r` Continue to next Return
* `s` Step Into
* `l` List
* `b` Breakpoint
* `q` Quit

### Dictionaries

Loop through keys and values in a dictionary: `for key, value in lookup_address.items()`.

Iterate through dictionary in key order: 

    for key in sorted(mydict.iterkeys()):
        print "%s: %s" % (key, mydict[key])

Assign matching key or default: `var = dict.get(key, default_value)`. Ditto and remove matching entry: `var = dict.pop(key, default_value)`.

### Exceptions

Access ongoing Exception information: `sys.exc_info()`:

* Capture last line of traceback and line describing problem to include in a message:

        from traceback import format_exc
        . . .
        except Exception as e:
            trace_info = format_exc(sys.exc_info()).split("\n")[-4:-2]

* Print traceback: `print 'traceback %s' % (traceback.extract_tb(sys.exc_info()[2]))`.

### Operators

Increment `[var] += 1`; Modulo `%`.

Ternary operator: `x if a > b else y` Return `x` is `a > b` otherwise return `y` (equivalent to `a > b ? x : y;` in Java).

### Interaction with Operating System

Directory containing current module: `cwd = os.path.realpath(os.path.dirname(__file__))`

Relative Paths: `DATABASE_NAME = os.path.expanduser('~/django-reversion/default.sqlite')` or `DATABASE_NAME = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'default.sqlite')`

Build path: `PROJECT_PATH = os.path.join(os.path.expanduser('~/code'),'fres/project')`

Run command: `p = Popen("grep -r --include='*.py' \"%s\" %s" % (string.strip(), PROJECT_PATH), shell=True, stdout=PIPE)`

Run a script from the Python shell: `execfile("/home/ahernp/test.py")`

To find where a module was imported from check its `.__file__` attribute.

### Slicing

* `a[start:end]` Items start through end-1.
* `a[start:]` Items start through the rest of the array.
* `a[:end]` Items from the beginning through end-1.
* `a[:]` A copy of the whole array.

A step value can be used with any of the above: `a[start:end:step]`. 

The `:end` value represents the first value that is not in the selected slice. The difference between end and start is the number of elements selected (if step is 1, the default). 

Also start or end may be a negative number, which means it counts from the end of the array instead of the beginning.

* `a[-1]` Last item in the array.
* `a[-2:]` Last two items in the array.
* `a[:-2]` Everything except the last two items.

Python is forgiving if there are fewer items than you ask for. For example, if you ask for `a[:-2]` and a only contains one element, you get an empty list instead of an error.

## Recipes

### Write File

    import codecs
    def write_file(filename, data):
        output_filepath = os.path.join(settings.PROJECT_DIR, filename)
        output_file = codecs.open(output_filepath, 'w', 'utf-8')
        output_file.write(data)
        output_file.close()
        print('Data written to %s' % (output_filepath))

Add to existing file: `open(output_filepath, 'a', 'utf-8')`

### Remove Substring

1. Find start of substring: `start_pos = big_string.index('/home/')`
1. Find end of substring: `end_pos = big_string.index("'",start_pos)`
1. Remove substring: `big_string = big_string[:start_pos] + big_string[end_pos:]`

To check if substring is present use: `start_pos = big_string.find('/home/')`

### FTP

    import ftplib
    . . .
    def ftp_to(filename, pdf_stringio):
        ftp_serv = ftplib.FTP(settings.FTP_HOSTNAME, 
                              settings.FTP_USERNAME, 
                              settings.FTP_PASSWORD)
        pdf_stringio.seek(0) # Put file position at beginning of StringIO
        resp = ftp_serv.storbinary('STOR ' + filename, pdf_stringio)
        ftp_serv.close

### Sort, Pickle, Hash

    import hashlib
    import cPickle as pickle
    . . .
    # hash a pickle of a sorted dictionary
    sorted_context = sorted(context.items(), key=lambda t: t[0])
    pickle_str = pickle.dumps(sorted_context)
    rml_hash = hashlib.sha224(pickle_str).hexdigest()

### Display Progress Percentage

Calculate and display percentage progress:

    rows = source_class.objects.using('legacy').all()
    total = len(rows)
    . . .
    for i, row in enumerate(rows):
       . . .
       percent = float(i) / total * 100
       sys.stdout.write("\r%2.3f%%" % percent)
       sys.stdout.flush()

Example shows percentage to three decimal places, to show percentage as integer use `"\r%2d%%"`.

### Default encoding

Check the default encoding in python at a terminal with the following commands:

    import sys
    sys.getdefaultencoding()

If it is `ascii` then you may get the following error `UnicodeError: ASCII encoding error: ordinal not in range(128)` when processing unicode data.

Avoid this by changing the default encoding to `utf-8` by adding the following as `sitecustomize.py` to the PYTHONPATH and restart python:

    # sitecustomize.py                                                              
    # this file can be anywhere in your Python path,                                
    # but it usually goes in ${pythondir}/lib/site-packages/                        
    import sys
    sys.setdefaultencoding('utf-8')
